title: Tropical Storm Hone : Hawaii faces flooding and road closures as three Cyclones stir in Pacific
message:
Tropical storm Hone brings heavy rain to HawaiiImpact on Big IslandPrecautions against future fires amid Tropical Storm HoneHurricane Gilma and Tropical Storm Hector gain strengthThree tropical cyclones were active in the Pacific Ocean on Monday, bringing varied effects to different regions.
Tropical Storm Hone caused significant rainfall and flash floods in Hawaii , while Hurricane Gilma and Tropical Storm Hector were gaining strength and moving eastward.The impacts of these storms led to road closures and power outages to potential future flooding concerns.Tropical Storm Hone, pronounced "hoe-NEH," caused road closures, downed power lines, and damaged trees in parts of the Big Island , according to William Ahue, a forecaster at the Central Pacific Hurricane Center in Honolulu.
"No major damage that we know of yet," news agency AP quoted Big Island mayor Mitch Roth as saying.
Additionally, four schools on the Big Island were closed because of power outages and flooded roads.
"We were experiencing tropical storm winds and heavy pounding rain through the night."
event_breakdown:
Tropical Storm Hone hits Hawaii, causes flooding, road closures, power outages.
Hurricane Gilma and Tropical Storm Hector gain strength, head towards Hawaii.
Three tropical cyclones active in Pacific Ocean, one hits Hawaii.

title: Tropical Storm Hone moves past Hawaii as two other cyclones stay active in the Pacific Ocean
message:
HONOLULU — Three tropical cyclones swirled over the Pacific Ocean on Monday, including Tropical Storm Hone which brought heavy rain to Hawaii, Hurricane Gilma which was gaining strength and Tropical Storm Hector which was churning westward, far off the coast of southern tip of Baja California.
“No major damage that we know of yet,” Big Island Mayor Mitch Roth said.
Four Big Island schools were closed because of power outages and flooded roads from Hone.
In the eastern Pacific Ocean, Hurricane Gilma intensified Monday into a strong Category 2 hurricane with maximum sustained winds at 110 mph.
Farther to the east, Tropical Storm Hector also gained strength Monday.
location: The main event is Tropical Storm Hone which caused heavy rain in Hawaii.
event_breakdown: Tropical Storm Gilma, Hurricane Hector, Tropical Storm Hone, Hawaii and Baja California.

title: Tropical Storm Hone moves past Hawaii as two other cyclones stay active in the Pacific Ocean
message:
Tropical Storm Hone moves past Hawaii as two other cyclones stay active in the Pacific OceanTropical Storm Hone moves past Hawaii as two other cyclones stay active in the Pacific Ocean View PhotoHONOLULU (AP) — Three tropical cyclones swirled over the Pacific Ocean on Monday, including Tropical Storm Hone, which brought heavy rain to Hawaii, Hurricane Gilma, which was gaining strength, and Tropical Storm Hector, which was churning westward, far off the coast of southern tip of Baja California.
By midday Monday, Hone was 280 miles (450 kilometers) west-southwest of Honolulu with maximum sustained winds of 65 mph (110 kph).
In the eastern Pacific Ocean, Hurricane Gilma intensified Monday into a strong Category 2 hurricane with maximum sustained winds at 110 mph (175 kph).
Gilma was located about 1,160 miles (1,865 kilometers) east of Hilo, Hawaii, and moving west at 8 mph (13 mph).
Farther to the east, Tropical Storm Hector also gained strength Monday.
event_breakdown: Tropical Storm Hone moves past Hawaii as two other cyclones stay active in the Pacific Ocean, includes descriptions of Tropical Storm Hone, Hurricane Gilma, and Tropical Storm Hector.

“No major damage that we know of yet,” Big Island Mayor Mitch Roth said.

Gilma was located about 1,160 miles (1,865 kilometers) east of Hilo, Hawaii, and moving west at 8 mph (13 mph).

title: Back - to - Back Hurricanes : Hawaii Could Face Gilma Less Than a Week After Hone
message:
Tropical Storm Hone began its pass of the islands as a Category 1 Hurricane on Aug. 25, diminishing to a tropical storm in the process.
National Hurricane Center's forecasted track for Hurricane Gilma on its way toward Hawaii as of 5 p.m. Eastern time on Aug. 26, 2024.
National Hurricane Center's forecasted track for Hurricane Gilma on its way toward Hawaii as of 5 p.m. Eastern time on Aug. 26, 2024.
National Hurricane Center/National Weather ServiceThe Hawaiian Islands could face back-to-back storms as the National Hurricane Center (NHC) forecasts Hurricane Gilma to arrive within striking distance by Labor Day Weekend—less than one week after Hurricane Hone.
There are currently three named storms in the Pacific, with Tropical Storm Hector following behind Gilma.
event_breakdown:
Tropical Storm Hone:

The National Hurricane Center's forecasted track for Hurricane Gilma is on its way towards Hawaii as of 5 p.m. Eastern time on Aug. 26, 2024. The U.S. Coast Guard has spearheaded evacuation operations to help residents prepare for the storm, and the Hawaii Emergency Management Agency warns against non-essential travel and are encouraging residents to stock up on food and obtain water, in addition to the usual preparations involving securing homes. According to data from the National Hurricane Center, this transition is set to happen on Friday evening.

Hurricane Hector:

Despite conflicts between Hawaii Emergency Management Agency and the white house, American Samoans are bracing for Hurricane Hector, which is on track to impact the territory on Wednesday around 2:15 p.m. It could also pass by Hawaii's main islands, reports Hawaii Emergency Management Agency. Panetta, along with the prime minster of Australia, Julia Gillard, are currently in Hawaii as part of President Obama's first state visit to Hawaii as president. The winds will be at over 85 mph and there have been flash flood warnings issued all over the island in the tropical depression's estimated path.

Hurricane Gilma:

Honolulu announced Tuesday that "non-essential travel should avoid the island archipelago until Gilma's path is confirmed".

Hurricane Hector:

American Samoa's National Weather Service announced that a hurricane stands as a threat on Wednesday, and that preparations should begin as soon as possible.

title: Earthquake of 5 . 9 magnitude strikes Darwin
message:
A strong earthquake measuring 5.9 on the Richter scale occurred in the Banda Sea , off the coast of Darwin , Australia , on Tuesday.
The seismic event was detected at a depth of 62 km.According to the Bureau of Meteorology, "there was no threat of a tsunami to Australia" following the earthquake.
Geoscience Australia received nearly 300 reports from individuals who felt the tremors.The significant seismic activity in the Banda Sea came shortly after a smaller, magnitude 3.0 earthquake struck the Gippsland region of Victoria on Monday evening at 7:54pm.The epicenter of this quake was located at Sandy Point, in close proximity to Wilsons Promontory, approximately 190km south-east of Melbourne.
location: The main event takes place in the Banda Sea.
event_breakdown:
Current natural-disaster events reported on in text:
Earthquake in the Banda Sea, off the coast of Darwin, Australia on Tuesday.

title: Magnitude 5 . 9 earthquake recorded off coast of Darwin
message:
An earthquake with a magnitude of 5.9 has been recorded off the coast of Darwin.
The earthquake was recorded in the Banda Sea at a depth of 62km at about midday on Tuesday.
Almost 300 people lodged reports on Geoscience Australia after feeling the quake, while some office workers in Darwin reported their buildings shaking.
Meanwhile, residents in NSW's Upper Hunter region and beyond were rattled by a magnitude 5.0 earthquake just after 12pm on Friday.
It came just hours after a magnitude 3.2 earthquake shook the nearby town of Muswellbrook at 1.10am with another magnitude 2.5 quake felt at 2.30am.
event_breakdown:
5.9 Magnitude Earthquake Recorded off Coast of Darwin
A 5.9 magnitude earthquake was recorded off the coast of Darwin. The earthquake was recorded in the Banda Sea at a depth of 62km at about midday on Tuesday. Almost 300 people lodged reports on Geoscience Australia after feeling the quake, while some office workers in Darwin reported their buildings shaking.

title: No more  wildfires of note  burning in B . C .
message:
There are no longer any "wildfires of note" burning in British Columbia, with the B.C.
The Corya Creek wildfire, about 170 kilometres northeast of Terrace, B.C., was the last fire to be tagged with the label, which was lifted on Monday.
Fire information officer Emilie Peacock cautions the changing status doesn't mean the wildfire season is over.
More than 10,000 square kilometres of land has been burned in B.C.
Last year's record wildfire season saw more than 28,000 square kilometres of land burned and forced the evacuations of communities in regions including the Okanagan and Shuswap.
event_breakdown:
B.C.
As of Sunday, there are no wildfires of note burning inB.C.

title: Megathrust Earthquake : BMKG Urges Ministry to Ensure Disaster Preparedness of Tourist Destinations
message:
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - The Meteorology, Climatology, and Geophysics Agency (BMKG) urged the Ministry of Tourist and Creative Economy to ensure beaches have earthquake and tsunami mitigation standards to respond to megathrust earthquake potential.
According to the BMKG Head of the Indian and Pacific Oceans Tsunami Mitigation Department, Suci Anugrah, many hotels and tourist destinations are neglecting the basic standards of earthquake and tsunami mitigation.
Suci said a megathrust earthquake is inevitable as it’s been analyzed through scientific studies.
Therefore, a structural mitigation plan is necessary since the precise timing of a megathrust earthquake cannot be predicted.
"Every tourism manager and related parties can refer to ISO emergency management in drafting evacuation and disaster mitigation standards," said Suci.
event_breakdown:
The following natural-disaster events were reported in the current time frame:

1. Earthquake: A 4.7-magnitude earthquake hit Cipatujah, Bogor, West Java, on Friday at 8.22 a.m. West Indonesia Standard Time (WIB), according to BMKG. The quake's epicenter was located at a depth of 10 kilometers (km) in Sukabumi regency.
2. Tsunami: Indonesia's Meteorology, Climatology, and Geophysics Agency (BMKG) urged the Ministry of Tourism and Creative Economy to ensure beaches have tsunami mitigation standards to respond to Indonesia's megathrust earthquake potential.

message:

Nickerson was hiking along Havasu Creek about a half-mile (800 meters) from where it meets up with the Colorado River when the flash flood struck.

title: Forecasters monitoring disturbance in Atlantic after weeks of relative calm
message:
After weeks of relative calm in the tropics, forecasters are monitoring a disturbance in the central Atlantic that could slowly develop over the next week.
Forecasters gave the disturbance a 0% chance of developing over the next 48 hours and a 20% chance of doing so over the next week.
The next named storm in the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season will be Francine.
• • •Tampa Bay Times hurricane coverage 20245 things to know about the 2024 hurricane season, according to forecasters.
Forecasters predict ‘extremely active’ 2024 hurricane season.
event_breakdown:
Tropical Storm Sonia 

Sonia is a tropical cyclone in the Pacific that was active on October 17, 2024. The storm was located approximately 1,200 miles due east of Hilo, Hawaii, and had maximum sustained winds of 65 miles per hour. Sonia is expected to move west-northwestward over the next few days and continue to strengthen. 

Hurricane Tomas 

Tomas, classified as a category 2 hurricane on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale, was located in the Atlantic and was active on October 29, 2024. The storm was located approximately 400 miles east-northeast of the northern Leeward Islands and was moving west-northwestward at 8 miles per hour. The storm had maximum sustained winds of 110 miles per hour. Tomas is expected to move across the northeastern Caribbean Sea over the next few days and may bring heavy rainfall and strong winds to the region.

title: NZ Peters downplays human - made climate change at PIF
message: "If we're going to help anyone with all the other tsunamis coming their way, such as the health tsunami, food supply tsunami, employment and economic tsunami ... we need to have a sound economy ourselves," he said.
event_breakdown:

Australia is suffering from torrential rain and deadly floods hitting major parts of New South Wales and Queensland. Twenty-five people have been killed so far, and thousands have fled their homes.

title: Pretty scary : Tropical Storm Hone lashes parts of Hawaii Island as a Cat 1 hurricane
message:
(HONOLULU) - Tens of thousands of Hawaii Electric customers were without power across the state as Tropical Storm Hone moved through the islands over the weekend.
It upgraded to a Category 1 Hurricane late Saturday as it brushed the southern point of Hawaii Island on Sunday.
As of late Sunday evening, Hone was downgraded back to tropical storm as it pulled away from the islands.
At 11:30 a.m. Sunday, roughly 18,000 HECO costumers were without power across the state, the majority of them on Hawaii Island.
Hawaii Island residents can report damages from Hurricane Hone here or call (808) 935-0031.
event_breakdown: Hurricane Hone hit Hawaii on July 25. It downgraded to a tropical storm then moved to the northeast of the islands. About 18,000 HECO customers were without power Sunday across the state.

title: B . C . lifts last  wildfire of note  designation as number of blazes drops below 300
message:
But fire information officer Emelie Peacock said the change doesn't mean the wildfire season is over and there are still a handful of evacuation orders and alerts impacting communities around the province.
The BC Wildfire Service dashboard on Monday afternoon showed the number of active blazes in the province had fallen to about 290, continuing a downward trend from Friday when there were about 340 fires burning.
The wildfire service update said B.C.
was "still in the core of our wildfire season," but firefighters were making the most of reduced fire behaviour and good weather.
The wildfire service said earlier that while much of the southern part of B.C.
event_breakdown:
BC, including Metro Vancouver, is expected to see showers and possibly some thunder Monday afternoon and evening, but conditions will be dry with "elevated wildfire risk" in the northern part of the province.
While no specific areas or regions are called out for the latest assessment map, the wildfire service noted that southwest B.C. continues to have an elevated fire risk due to "hot, dry, and windy conditions."
Ongoing fire-fighting efforts are focused on nearly a dozen wildfires of note, including 10 that are considered highly visible or potentially threatening, and one that is just being monitored.
- A large wildfire southeast of Kamloops continues to grow and has prompted new evacuation orders over the weekend.
Despite the overall decrease in the number of wildfires in B.C., there are still a handful of evacuation orders and alerts impacting communities around the province.

title: Disaster unemployment assistance available to Vermonters who lost work during July 9 - 10 flooding​
message:
The U.S. Department of Labor has approved federal disaster unemployment assistance for Vermonters who lost work because of the flooding from the remnants of Hurricane Beryl on July 9 and 10, the state Labor Department said Monday.
Last week, President Joe Biden approved a major disaster declaration for parts of the state that were hit by the flooding, including individual assistance disaster, which covers unemployment assistance, for residents in Addison, Caledonia, Chittenden, Essex, Lamoille, Orleans and Washington counties, the state said.
Heavy rains washed out roads in Vermont in the latest round of flooding to hit the state.
“Vermonters across the State have found their lives, homes, and businesses impacted again by this recent disaster,” Labor Commissioner Michael Harrington said in a statement.
The Labor Department will determine if the individual is eligible for regular unemployment or should apply for the federal benefit.
event_breakdown:
Tropical Storm Agatha killed at least 9 people and left 20 missing in Guatemala.  Agatha caused severe flooding and landslides.  A state of emergency was declared.  Agatha formed on May 24 and dissipated on May 30.
Tropical Storm Cindy killed at least five people in the states of Louisiana and Alabama.  It caused severe flooding across the two states and was classified as a low-end flood event.  At least 22 deaths were blamed on Cindy, and the storm caused power outages that affected over 100,000 people.

title: Clean - up efforts begin on Hawaii island as Hurricane Hone passes through
message:
HILO, Hawaii (KHON2) — Hawaii island is cleaning up from Hurricane Hone.
While no severe damages were reported, major roads remain closed and some have been without power since Saturday night.
Kauai County: No major impacts from Hone, monitoring looming storms in Eastern PacificFrom Kohala to Kau, Hone dumped over a foot of rain on parts of Hawaii island and some roads were damaged.
Some volcano residents had power back on by 9 p.m. on Sunday night.
The county is hosting two hazard mitigation meetings over the next two days where residents can provide comments and feedback.
event_breakdown: Hawaii island is cleaning up from Hurricane Hone, which dumped over a foot of rain on parts of the island. No severe damages were reported, but major roads remain closed and some residents have been without power since Saturday night. The county is hosting two hazard mitigation meetings where residents can provide comments and feedback.

Tropical storm dumps heavy rain on HawaiiThree tropical cyclones swirled over the Pacific Ocean on Monday, including Tropical Storm Hone, which brought heavy rain to Hawaii, Hurricane Gilma, which was gaining strength, and Tropical Storm Hector which was churning westward, far off the coast of southern tip of Baja California.
Deadly Alaska landslide crashes into homesA landslide that cut a path down a steep, thickly forested hillside crashed into several homes in Ketchikan, Alaska, in the latest such disaster to strike the mountainous region.

Nickerson was hiking along Havasu Creek about a half-mile (800 meters) from where it meets up with the Colorado River when the flash flood struck.

2. A series of wildfires are burning across the western United States, causing evacuations and poor air quality. 
3. A landslide killed one person and damaged several homes in Ketchikan, Alaska. 
4. The Grand Canyon National Park had an incident where a flash flood caused the death of a hiker.

title: B . C . lifts last  wildfire of note  designation as number of blazes drops below 300
message:
VANCOUVER — There are no longer any "wildfires of note" burning in British Columbia, with the BC Wildfire Service saying favourable weather had allowed crews to make good progress in the province's battle against hundreds of blazes.
The BC Wildfire Service dashboard on Monday afternoon showed the number of active blazes in the province had fallen to about 290, continuing a downward trend from Friday when there were about 340 fires burning.
The wildfire service update said B.C.
was "still in the core of our wildfire season," but firefighters were making the most of reduced fire behaviour and good weather.
The wildfire service said earlier that while much of the southern part of B.C.

title: Red Cross : Weather continuing to take a toll on U . S . blood supplies | News , Sports , Jobs
message:
PARKERSBURG — Severe weather has further strained the blood supply, the American Red Cross said.
The Red Cross continues to experience a national blood emergency as remnants of Hurricane Debby and other severe weather across the country have further complicated efforts to rebuild the nation’s blood supply, the agency said.
Annually, severe weather such as blizzards, tornadoes, flooding and hurricanes impacts about 90,000 blood donations made to the Red Cross.
To make an appointment, download the Red Cross Blood Donor App, visit RedCrossBlood.org or call 1-800-RED CROSS (1-800-733-2767).
Those who give Sept. 1-15 will receive a Red Cross raglan T-shirt, while supplies last.
event_breakdown: Severe weather across the country has further strained the blood supply, as remnants of Hurricane Debby continue to complicate efforts to rebuild the nation's blood supply, the American Red Cross said. Annually, severe weather such as blizzards, tornadoes, flooding, and hurricanes impacts about 90,000 blood donations made to the Red Cross. To make an appointment, download the Red Cross Blood Donor App, visit RedCrossBlood.org, or call 1-800-RED CROSS (1-800-733-2767).

title: Storms drop significant amount of hail along South Coast - Boston News , Weather , Sports
message:
(WHDH) - Pop-up thunderstorms that hit parts of southern New England dropped a significant amount of hail on several South Coast communities Monday.
Videos and photos documented hail falling across the South Coast and Cape Cod.
The National Weather Service documented additional flooding in Dennis.
The National Weather Service issued several severe thunderstorm warnings and flash flood warnings Monday.
A larger severe thunderstorm watch was scheduled to remain in effect across much of southern New England until 7 p.m.Stay with 7NEWS on-air and online for the latest updates on severe weather.
event_breakdown:
1. Flash flooding hits different communities in southern New England earlier today.
2. Flooding in Dennis.
3. Hail falls in different parts of the state.
4. The National Weather Service issues several severe thunderstorm warnings.

title: The 2024 hurricane season is not dead : Ryan Phillips – NBC 6 South Florida
message:
The 2005 hurricane season was an extreme example of epic atmospheric performance orchestrated, in tandem, with epic fatigue for all who endured it.
It was 15 years later that a hurricane season combined the right ingredients to produce more storms (30) with more Gulf Coast landfalls than 2005.
The Hurricane season is on.
But as it stands, I’m left with a few sturdy reminders to share as we enter the heart of the season.
A late-August lull has produced doubt about what the second part of hurricane season may look like.
event_breakdown:
Late August is an excellent time for surplus training, maintenance, and recovery for all skill sets for a particular function or organization for an intense disaster, typically from a hurricane in South Florida.
Hurricane season's second half's upcoming intensity is unsure after the first appearance scare in late August

title: Tropical Storm Hone moves past Hawaii as two other cyclones stay active in the Pacific Ocean | News , Sports , Jobs
message:
By JENNIFER SINCO KELLEHER and JULIE WALKER Associated PressHONOLULU (AP) — Three tropical cyclones swirled over the Pacific Ocean on Monday, including Tropical Storm Hone, which brought heavy rain to Hawaii, Hurricane Gilma, which was gaining strength, and Tropical Storm Hector, which was churning westward, far off the coast of southern tip of Baja California.
“No major damage that we know of yet,” Big Island Mayor Mitch Roth said.
Four Big Island schools were closed because of power outages and flooded roads from Hone.
Gilma was located about 1,160 miles (1,865 kilometers) east of Hilo, Hawaii, and moving west at 8 mph (13 mph).
Farther to the east, Tropical Storm Hector also gained strength Monday.
event_breakdown: Tropical Storm Hector and Hurricane Gilma are swirling over the Pacific Ocean on Monday. Tropical Storm Hone is bringing heavy rain to Hawaii.

title: Hurricane - season fire , power risks garner more attention
message:
HONOLULU (KHON2) — Top emergency management officials said with this hurricane season, extra attention is on even more threats than before.
Clean-up efforts begin on Hawaii island as Hurricane Hone passes throughLong after Hurricane Hone had passed Hawaii island, and shelters meant to protect from wind, rain and flooding had closed, Hawaii County announced the re-opening of two shelters in parks for one specific reason: power.
KHON2 asked James Barros, administrator of the Hawaii Emergency Management Agency, about the elevated attention to power outages.
DOH plans change to ocean water testing during brown water advisories“We do, and we would be looking at our federal partners for assistance during an extended power shutdown,” Barros said.
So I’m more worried towards the end of hurricane season than I am at the beginning.”Copyright 2024 Nexstar Media, Inc. All rights reserved.
event_breakdown:
Hurricane Hector, Hurricane John, Hurricane Kristy
Hawaii Emergency Management Agency

title: Storm tracker : National Hurricane Center tracking new disturbance in central Atlantic
message:
The National Hurricane Center is tracking a new disturbance in the central Atlantic Ocean, the agency said in its latest advisory.
The National Hurricane Center is tracking a new disturbance in the central Atlantic Ocean, the agency said in its latest advisory Tuesday.
The storm was moving west at about 8 miles per hour on Monday evening as maximum sustained winds declined to about 100 mph, according to the National Hurricane Center.
Before its forecasted gradual weakening, the center said Gilma will likely "remain a hurricane as it approaches the central Pacific basin."
This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: National Hurricane Center tracking new disturbance in central Atlantic
event_breakdown: National Hurricane Center tracks new disturbance in central Atlantic

title: National Hurricane Center tracking new disturbance in Atlantic . Is quiet period over ?
message:
National Hurricane Center tracking new disturbance in Atlantic.
The National Hurricane Center is tracking a new disturbance in the central Atlantic, according to the latest advisory.
The Pacific continues to be busy — with the National Hurricane Center currently tracking two tropical storms and one hurricane.
The National Hurricane Center was monitoring a tropical disturbance and two tropical waves in the Atlantic basin, according to the 8 a.m. advisory.
National Hurricane Center map: What are forecasters watching now?
event_breakdown: National Hurricane Center is tracking a new disturbance in the central Atlantic. Other than that, the Pacific is busy. Two tropical storms and a hurricane are being monitored in the National Hurricane Center. In addition, tropical waves are also being watched in the Central Atlantic. Reports elsewhere in the world include the probability of a cyclone in southwestern Bangladesh.

title: Tsunami Risk Looms Over Yogyakarta Coast After Quake from Megathrust Zone
message:
TEMPO.CO, Bandung - The 5.8-magnitude earthquake, later updated to 5.5-magnitude, that shook Yogyakarta and other areas on the southern coast of Java on Monday night, August 26, 2024, was caused by the activity of the subduction zone or megathrust zone.
The quake’s epicenter, which occurred at 19:57 western Indonesian time (WIB), was closer to Yogyakarta Province compared to other areas.
“According to data from the Geological Agency, residential areas affected by the tremors are primarily located in the Disaster Prone Area (KRB) for medium to high earthquakes,” he said.
Tsunami Threat of Over 3 MetersHadi explained that the quake did not cause a tsunami despite its origin in the megathrust zone.
AHMAD FIKRI (CONTRIBUTOR)Editor’s Choice: BMKG: Tonight's Earthquake in Yogyakarta from Megathrust ZoneClick here to get the latest news updates from Tempo on Google News
event_breakdown: The Yogyakarta earthquake from the current time frame can be seen in the map at Yogyakarta, Indonesia.

message:
A light earthquake with magnitude 4.5 (ml/mb) was detected on Tuesday, 60 kilometers (37 miles) from Kangding in China.
The earthquake occurred at a depth of 10 km (6 miles).
Id of earthquake: us6000nmvn.
Epicenter of the earthquake was 66 km (41 miles) from Kangding (c. 100 000 pop).

title: Rain , cooler weather end campfire ban on Vancouver Island - Victoria Times Colonist
message:
Fire danger ratings across most of Vancouver Island are listed as very low, with some areas on the South Island listed as low.
Wildfire Service said recent rains and cooler temperatures will allow it to lift the campfire ban on Vancouver Island as of noon on Wednesday.
Fire danger ratings across most of the Island are listed as very low, with some areas on the South Island listed as low.
Wildfire Service said in a statement.
In last year’s record wildfire season, more than 28,000 square kilometres of land was burned, forcing the evacuations of communities in regions such as the Okanagan and the Shuswap.
event_breakdown: Fire danger ratings across most of Vancouver Island are listed as very low, with some areas on the South Island listed as low. A campfire ban has been lifted across the island and residents will be allowed to build campfires as of noon on Wednesday. Until recently, a series of rain storms helped reduce the fire danger for the island. During last year's record wildfire season, over 28,000 square kilometres of the island was burned, forcing survivors to evacuate, according to the Wildfire Service.

title: UK Hurricane warning : Expert says  big beast  to hit Britain | Weather | News
message:
The dissipation of dry sandy air off the Sahara could have implications for the UK, said Jim DaleThere are rising expectations of a “huge up-step” in the hurricane season next month, with a meteorologist warning a “big beast” could lash the UK within days.
Jim Dale, of British Weather Services, was speaking days after Storm Lilian barrelled over Britain, downing trees and causing significant travel disruption.
And he suggested more is in the pipeline once autumn arrives, telling Express.co.uk: "There’s rising expectations of a huge up-step in the hurricane season as we head into September and October.
“Six to eight big beasts are not out of the question, with some akin to the first two eventually heading our way.
We've had heavy rain in the north of the UK through this morning ?
event_breakdown: Heavy rain in the north of the UK.

title: TROPICS : A new area of possible development in the Atlantic
message:
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — The National Hurricane Center on Tuesday is watching a new area of unsettled weather in the central Atlantic for possible development.
A tropical wave will approach the Lesser Antilles as we get closer to the weekend or early next week.
This wave may become a tropical depression or storm.
WPTVTRACKING THE TROPICS: Hurricane Center | Hurricane GuideFor now, it has a 20% chance of development.
We have plenty of time to track it," WPTV First Alert Weather meteorologist Jennifer Correa said.
location: Based on the text, the most specific location where the main event takes place is 'the Lesser Antilles'.
event_breakdown:
Hurricane Larry, Tropical Storm Mindy
National Hurricane Center is watching a new troubled weather area in central Atlantic that may become tropical depression or storm by weekend or early next week
Weather monitoring of unnamed storm system

title: Wilton in  recovery  after  100 - year flood  damages roads , fields
message:
The floodwaters carried debris throughout the town, depositing large amounts of dirt on the high school’s track at Tom Fujitani Field, flooding town fields, and washing out ponds, officials said.
One of the more lasting impacts of the storm and flooding is the closure of Scribner Hill Road, Blanchfield said.
The road is closed between Blue Ridge Road and “just before” Rockhouse Road, Blanchfield said.
The town’s emergency response team, comprising police, fire, and the first selectwoman, have been meeting daily to assess damage and further plan, Blanchfield said.
Regardless, the town’s teams will likely conduct door-to-door damage assessments in the Newtown Turnpike and Arrowhead areas of Wilton, he said.
event_breakdown: ['Wilton, CT, Heavy flooding hit the town on June 30, damaging several roads, including Scribner Hill Road, and forcing officials to close it indefinitely.']

title: As B . C . last  wildfire of note  vacates the danger zone , battle not over yet
message:
Peacock said southern parts of the province saw heavy rain recently, but parts of the north continue to experience drought conditions.
The wildfire service update said B.C.
was “still in the core of our wildfire season,” but firefighters were making the most of reduced fire behaviour and good weather.

In last year’s record wildfire season, more than 28,000 square kilometres of land was burned, forcing the evacuations of communities in regions such as the Okanagan and the Shuswap.

title: Severe storm threat in forecast for Chicago area this week – NBC Chicago
message:
The Chicago area is going to see near-record heat and oppressive humidity on Tuesday, but the threat of severe weather also exists, with gusty winds and heavy rain possible.
According to the Storm Prediction Center, the Chicago area is at a “slight” risk of severe weather Tuesday, with wind gusts up to 60 miles per hour and heavy rains possible.
Those readings could threaten records in Chicago, but more importantly could cause heat indices of 110-to-115 degrees across the area.
The threat of rain will continue into Wednesday, with isolated showers and thunderstorms possible throughout the day.
Stay tuned to the NBC Chicago app and the NBC 5 Storm Team for all the latest weather news and information.
event_breakdown:
1.Severe weather to hit the Chicago area.
2.Severe weather and high winds expected Tuesday in Chicago. 
3.Extreme heat to descend on Chicago again today with severe storms possible. Alternatively, 
4.Severe heat and risk of severe weather Tuesday in Chicago.

title: Wild week of US weather includes heat wave , tropical storm , landslide , flash flood and snow
message:
FALCON HEIGHTS, Minn. (AP) — It's been a wild week of weather in many parts of the United States, from heat waves to snowstorms to flash floods.
The National Weather Service issued heat warnings or advisories across Minnesota, Iowa, South Dakota, Illinois, Kansas, Missouri, Nebraska, Wisconsin and Oklahoma.
Tropical storm dumps heavy rain on HawaiiThree tropical cyclones swirled over the Pacific Ocean on Tuesday, including Tropical Storm Hone, which brought heavy rain to Hawaii; Hurricane Gilma, which was weakening; and Tropical Storm Hector, which was churning westward, far off the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula of Mexico.
Flash flood hits Grand Canyon National ParkThe body of an Arizona woman who disappeared in Grand Canyon National Park after a flash flood was recovered Sunday, park rangers said.
Nickerson was hiking along Havasu Creek about a half-mile (800 meters) from where it meets up with the Colorado River when the flash flood struck.
event_breakdown:
Tropical Storm Rosa dumps rain on Mexico
Heat wave bakes central, eastern U.S.
Flash flood hits Grand Canyon National Park
Three tropical cyclones swirl in Pacific

title: National Hurricane Center Monitoring Tropical Wave in Atlantic
message:
The Gulf Coast is bracing for the peak of hurricane season and now the National Hurricane Center is monitoring an area of disturbed weather.
We will continue to monitor this tropical wave and provide more updates here and on this station's mobile app in the days ahead.
Meteorologists predict that the Atlantic will become more active in the weeks ahead as this hurricane season was predicted to be one of the most active in modern history.
So far, the season has been tame, but again, we are approaching the peak of hurricane season as we enter the month of September.
Hurricane season officially ends on November 30th.
location: The Gulf Coast of the United States.
event_breakdown: The Gulf Coast is bracing for the peak of hurricane season. There is no specific event to map for this time frame.

title: NZ Peters downplays human - made climate change at PIF
message: "If we're going to help anyone with all the other tsunamis coming their way, such as the health tsunami, food supply tsunami, employment and economic tsunami ... we need to have a sound economy ourselves," he said.
event_breakdown: Natural disaster: A  6.2 magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of Alaska on Wednesday, according to the US Geological Survey. The quake was centered about 55 miles west of Sand Point, Alaska, and around 480 miles northeast of Anchorage. The earthquake was reportedly felt across the Alaska Peninsula and into parts of southwest Alaska. There were no immediate reports of damage or injury.

title: Thailand Braces For More Rain After Floods , Landslide Killed 22
message:
(PHOTO / AFP)Thailand is bracing for more tropical rainstorms after 22 people died in flash floods and landslides over the past week.
The flooding has affected more than 33,000 households in 13 provinces since Aug. 16, killing nine people, the Department of Disaster Prevention and Mitigation said in a statement Tuesday.
While floods have receded from their peak, about 10,000 households in four provinces remain affected.
A tropical depression is expected to strengthen through Wednesday, bringing more rain to northern, northeastern and southern provinces, the disaster mitigation agency said.
The government hasn’t provided information on the cost of damage to farm output nor to infrastructure from this month’s calamity.
event_breakdown:
Thailand floods

Thailand is bracing for more tropical rainstorms after 22 people died in flash floods and landslides over the past week.

title: TROPICS : A new area of possible development in the Atlantic
message:
The National Hurricane Center on Tuesday is watching a new area of unsettled weather in the central Atlantic for possible development.
A tropical wave will approach the Lesser Antilles as we get closer to the weekend or early next week.
This wave may become a tropical depression or storm.
46419671-WPTV_Tropical Outlook-Auto.pngTRACKING THE TROPICS: Hurricane Center | Hurricane GuideFor now, it has a 20% chance of development.
We have plenty of time to track it," WPTV First Alert Weather meteorologist Jennifer Correa said.
event_breakdown:
The National Hurricane Center on Tuesday is watching a new area of unsettled weather in the central Atlantic for possible development.
A tropical wave will approach the Lesser Antilles as we get closer to the weekend or early next week.
This wave may become a tropical depression or storm.

For now, it has a 20% chance of development.
We have plenty of time to track it," WPTV First Alert Weather meteorologist Jennifer Correa said.

title: Crabs , stingrays & fish dying in Little Sarasota Bay after Hurricane Debby
message:
SARASOTA, Fla. (WFLA) — Hurricane Debby dropped massive amounts of rain on Sarasota County, inundating some neighborhoods with feet of water.
Sarasota Bay Estuary Program Director Dr. David Tomasko said samples collected in Lower Sarasota Bay show run-off from the storm is impacting water quality in the area weeks later.
NHC monitoring potential tropical disturbance in AtlanticLast week, sampling conducting in Little Sarasota Bay found low to virtually no oxygen on the sea floor.
Tomasko said restoring the historic tidal connection would help flush pollutants out of Sarasota Bay after storms like Debby.
What we have seen in Little Sarasota Bay is the same thing we saw after Hurricane Ian and our water quality in Little Sarasota Bay is the worst part, even though it doesn’t get the greatest amount of runoff in the area.”The estuary program will be back out later this week to collect additional samples in lower Sarasota Bay.
event_breakdown:
1. Hurricane Debby dropped massive amounts of rain on Sarasota County, inundating some neighborhoods with feet of water.
2. Sarasota Bay Estuary Program Director Dr. David Tomasko said samples collected in Lower Sarasota Bay show run-off from the storm is impacting water quality in the area weeks later.
3. Last week, sampling conducting in Little Sarasota Bay found low to virtually no oxygen on the sea floor.
4. Tomasko said restoring the historic tidal connection would help flush pollutants out of Sarasota Bay after storms like Debby.

title: How the Havasupai Tribe warns of flooding during monsoon season
message:
“We had multiple thunderstorms across the area, multiple warnings issued both Wednesday and again on Thursday,” said National Weather Service Flagstaff Meteorologist-In-Charge Brian Klimowski.
Given its location and limited access to cell service, the Havasupai Tribe says it does not have a warning system in place.
And that’s really what we rely on most heavily when something like this occurs,” said Havasupai Tribe Spokesperson Abbie Fink.
Last week’s monsoon was not the first time this area dealt with flooding.
Klimowski says it’s important to have an escape plan before hiking in a canyon or an area prone to flooding.
location: The main event takes place in Supai, Arizona.
event_breakdown: Havasupai tribal leaders are calling for better notifications to residents about potential flash flooding.

title: Suffolk County eyes FEMA funds to repair trail of storm damage
message:
Suffolk County officials said the dam would have to be replaced, joining a list of homes, roads and other facilities damaged by the record rainfall.
“What we're facing is an ecological, an environmental, and an economic disaster,” Suffolk County Executive Edward P. Romaine told Newsday on Monday.
What to know Suffolk County officials are eyeing federal emergency funds to repair or replace infrastructure damaged during last week's storms.
